creator: michael.grimes@marsh.com
text:
This "bug" has been noticed on XP, and 2K platforms on versions from 1.8 to the 
most recent nightly builds.  I can not isolate the problem to a specific 
network configuration at our end or if the problem exists within the Jmeter 
framework.  Without the proxy server I get page responses in 2-3 seconds, but 
with the proxy in place I have to wait up to 6 minutes between clicks.  This is 
starting to hamper my career now.  A long time ago I had a proxy server running 
and recording just fine.  It was about 4-6 seconds per page (double without 
times), but unfortuneatly those early versions of Jmeter were pretty 
barebones.  Help and/or a solution would be greatly appreciated. PS. Badboy 
captures information quickly, but it missing 1/2 the required tags and values, 
if that helps with trying to troubleshoot.

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
I've used JMeter on my home PC (Win XP) with the proxy recorder, and it works 
fine for me.

It could perhaps be a DNS issue - what happens if you run a local Tomcat or 
Apache httpd on the same system, and use the proxy to record a session using 
localhost?

Are you running a firewall or suchlike?

Thanks for the rapid response Sebb,

I considered the same things. I was originally testing from Toronto against 
application servers located in DeMoins Iowa.  I tried installing Jmeter on a 
component server within the DeMoins firewalls and going against the AppServers 
down there.  Samething.  Finally I tried running a BEA Weblogic Server on 
localhost on my laptop.  Same responses.  1-2 second responses without the 
proxy, 4-6 minutes with the proxy.

I have a Symantec Desktop Firewall installed, but it is currently "Disabled".  
Our applications actually fail with the firewall "enabled", so I can tell when 
it is active and not.

creator: sarah_karram@yahoo.ca
michael.grimes@marsh.com
text:
-- last comment by sarah_karram was actually Mike Grimes and a token flub --
 - my appologies -

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
Only thing I can suggest is turning on full debugging.

This might perhaps give enough information to narrow down where the extra time 
is being spent.

It might then be necessary to add a bit more debugging.

I've not tried BEA Weblogic. It seems unlikely that this would cause the slow-
down, but it might perhaps be worth trying a local Tomcat/Apache just in case.

creator: michael.grimes@marsh.com
text:
Following Sebb's advice I turned logging on.

When I turned on the logging I got some strange behaviour.  The recording proxy 
was actually fast.  I thought I would just have to leave logging on, and that 
would be a work-around.  No-go though.  After about 4 items were captured in 
a "Simple Controller" on a proxy that excluded: .*/.js .*/.css .*/.gif .*/.jpg 
there was consistantly a 34-35 second delay between these two lines:

2004/04/28 13:28:34 DEBUG - jmeter.protocol.http.sampler.HTTPSampler: Start : 
samplehttp://server:port/Application/document/resource/StyleSheet.css

2004/04/28 13:29:08 DEBUG - jmeter.protocol.http.sampler.HTTPSampler: Location 
set to - null

This occured for *.gif, *.jpg, *.css, *.js (non-captured) *.html (captured)
but not any of our struts actions *.do

The struts actions were captured almost instantly with POSTs and GETs and 
appeared much differently in the log.  Thus if a page has a style sheet, a 
javascript validator and a few tiny gifs it will take 3+ minutes.

Is there some chance that there is a "send buffer" on the proxy for embedded 
objects that timeouts after 35 seconds?

This happened against our internal applications and external sites 
(www.google.ca, jakarta.apache.org/jmeter).

creator: michael.grimes@marsh.com
text:
I have discovered and isolated the problem.

Java 1.3.1_01 and 1.3.1_02 do not work very well with Jmeter 2_0_0.  I was 
using the older versions of java because that is what we have running our 
production BEA servers.

I have switched to 1.5.0-beta and the problem does not seem to occur anymore.

-Sebb, thanks again for all your time and consideration on this issue!
